transcription.full_text: How's it going guys? Welcome back to the Patriot DIY channel. In this video I'm going to be showing you how to add LED backlighting to your shelves. Alright guys, if you have a home bar or some shelves at home that you want to add some backlighting to, this is the video for you. Now I built these upper cabinets and shelves in a previous video. If you want to check that out, I'll put a link to that right here at the top of the screen. I love the way this looks and it fits perfectly here in my man cave, but today I want to add some backlighting to these shelves. This is going to be a pretty simple project that almost anybody can do, and I'm going to show you step by step how I'm going to do this. But first guys, if you haven't done it yet, make sure you hit that subscribe button down below, hit that notification bell, and give us a thumbs up. The main thing you're going to need for this project is going to be your LED strip lighting. Now you can use any LED strip lighting. You can use any LED strip lights that you want. This just happens to be the ones that I picked up. These are off Amazon, and I will have a link to these in the description below. Now I chose this one specifically for this project for a couple reasons. First, because of the shape of the strip itself. It gives me a nice wide surface here on the side to attach it to the back of my shelf, and it's going to direct all the light upwards, which is exactly what we want for the back of our shelves. Now one issue with a lot of LED strip lights is you don't get a constant stream of light. You're going to see a dot of light where every little LED is. And I chose these specifically because the LEDs are diffused and it gives you a nice constant stream of light. You can see here that you don't see each individual dot of the LEDs. You just get a long continuous light. Now I think these are going to be great for the back lighting on our shelves, but because this is so flexible, this could be used to create any type of design on your wall. You can spell out letters with it or anything you want to do. So I'm going to go ahead and do that. Now with that said, let's get everything taken down off of these shelves and get to work. Once I get everything taken down off of these shelves, I can remove them from the wall and get ready to install my lights. All right guys, so we have a few different options. We have a few different options. We have a few different options. We have a few different options. We have a few different options for how we can attach our LED lights to our shelves. The first option would be just to stick the LED strip to the back of the shelf like this using either double-sided tape or hot glue. And as long as you have a gap between your shelf and the wall, this would work out fine. Another option would be to use these little clips that came with the LEDs. You just screw these down to the board and then the LED fits right into that little clip. For my application. The way I would do that is I would attach the LED strip directly to the top of the shelf. Then I'd cut another narrow strip of wood and attach that in front of my LEDs. That way it hides them from view, but still allows the light to shine on the wall behind the shelf. The next option would be just to cut or route a channel directly into the top or bottom of the shelf, whichever direction you want your light. We'll cut that channel the same width as our LED strip, and then it'll just fit down into that groove. Like an inlay. It'll be perfectly hidden, but still shine up in the direction that we want it. I think that'll give us the cleanest possible look. And it's pretty simple to do as long as you have a table saw or a router that you can route that channel with. So I think that's what I'm going to do. Let me know what you guys think in the comment section below. Which method would you use for attaching these to your shelves? First I need to set the height of my table saw blade to just a little more than the height of my table saw blade. I'm going to set it to about 1.5 inches. So I'm going to set it to about 1.5 inches. So I'm going to set it to about 1.5 inches. So I'm going to set it to about 1.5 inches. Then I'll run my shelf through the table saw cutting a groove all the way down. Now this groove is obviously not wide enough for the light to fit into yet. So I need to move my table saw fence over and then run the board back through, widening that groove. i'm going to keep doing that a little bit at a time test fitting the light as i go until i get a perfect fit now you are able to cut this light at designated spots along the strip so i'm going to test fit this light and mark the length that i need and then cut it down to size to attach this permanently i'm going to run a bead of hot glue down that groove and then fit this light down into place then i'll press it down to make sure it sits just below the top surface of the shelf you can see now that this gives us a nice clean professional look and we're ready to go the only thing left to do now is to reinstall our shelves on the wall and route our wires on the bottom shelf i've cut a small notch onto the end of the board and i'm going to be running this wire up under my cabinet then on this middle shelf i've cut a notch into the back of the cabinet so i can route the wires behind it and then down to our outlet guys. So now we've got our LED strips inlaid into our shelves. We've got our shelves back installed and I routed the wires back behind my upper cabinets down and behind my refrigerator. Now these light kits do come with a little touch sensor switch that you can put in line with the lights. This is going to do a couple things for you. You can adjust the brightness level. You can also turn it on and off with this switch here. But what I decided to do instead was to plug it into one of these wireless remote control outlets. You just plug your lights into the receiver and then you have this handy dandy little wall switch that you can mount anywhere you want to. It works exactly like a remote so all you have to do is... And there you go. Now this same switch controls my neon signs and my string lights that I have up along the ceiling. So with just one click I can turn all that on at the same time. I love the way this looks guys. I love that light shining up. Now let's get the stuff back up on these shelves and take a look at the final product. All right guys that's it for how to add back lighting to your shelves. I hope this video helped you out. If you guys have any other methods that you guys would use to do this make sure you let us know in the comment section below. I love you guys. I love you. Bye. I love how this turned out guys. I thought these shelves looked good already but this just added a whole nother level. Now don't forget guys I will have links to all the products we used in the description below if you want to do a project like this for yourself. So thanks for watching guys. Please like, share, and subscribe and we'll see you next time. Your

frames.analysis:
1. The image shows a workbench with various tools such as pliers, wrenches, and what appears to be construction materials. The lighting challenges are primarily in terms of evenness and brightness of the workspace. There are darker areas, particularly near the tools where shadows are cast, which could hinder visibility when working.

2. To address these lighting issues, it seems like a combination of ambient and task lighting is being used or demonstrated. The overhead light provides general illumination, while the presence of small lights (possibly LEDs) or flashlights suggests that localized task lighting might be necessary for specific tasks or areas with insufficient ambient light.

3. There are no specific products mentioned or shown directly in this image, but it does hint at the use of LED lights or similar portable lighting solutions. The presence of a notebook and pen indicates that some manual light adjustments might also take place.

4. The context appears to be a DIY or repair workspace, where good lighting is essential for precision tasks such as working with tools or small parts. The mood seems to be one of organization and preparedness, as evidenced by the neat arrangement of the tools.

1. Visible lighting problems or challenges: The room appears to be poorly lit for optimal video quality. The shadows are harsh and cast on the person's face, which can make them look unflattering or less appealing in the recording. The uneven distribution of light might also make it difficult to see some objects clearly in the background.

2. Lighting solutions or techniques demonstrated: There is a focus on natural light coming through the window, indicating that the speaker might be highlighting the importance of natural lighting. However, there is no specific artificial lighting technique being demonstrated, such as the use of softboxes or diffused light to reduce harsh shadows and improve evenness.

3. Specific lighting products mentioned or shown: There are no distinct lighting products shown in this frame. The focus seems to be on the discussion rather than showcasing a particular product.

4. Lighting context (room type, task, mood): The room has a rustic feel with natural wood elements and an informal setting. The task appears to be a casual interview or discussion, as evidenced by the person's hand gesture which is often used in conversation. The mood seems relaxed yet somewhat subdued due to the low lighting conditions.

To address these challenges, one could consider introducing soft diffused light sources near the subject to soften shadows and improve the overall lighting ambiance of the room. This would create a more professional look for both the person being interviewed and the background elements. Additionally, ensuring that all objects in the background are well-lit can help enhance the depth and overall visual quality of the video frame.

The image shows a person engaging in an activity that appears to involve a roll of paper or a similar material, which they are holding with one hand while stretching it out with the other. This suggests some sort of DIY project or crafting activity.

1. Lighting Problems: From what is visible, there is no significant light source focused on the activity. The room lighting is diffuse and does not provide strong, direct illumination where needed for precise work. There are shadows cast by the person's hand and body, indicating that the ambient light is coming from one direction.

2. Lighting Solutions: It appears that the person is using a tool or method to enhance the lighting on the material they are handling. This could be a portable flashlight or a small illuminated device, which they are holding in their other hand. The purpose of this additional light source is to provide focused and controlled light for the task at hand.

3. Specific Lighting Products Mentioned/Shown: There is no explicit mention or visible product name related to lighting solutions. However, we can infer that a portable LED flashlight or a similar device is being used due to its appearance and function in the photo.

4. Lighting Context: The room appears to be an indoor space with concrete flooring. The mood of the image seems casual and focused on the task at hand rather than the aesthetics of the environment, which is typical for DIY or crafting activities. There are no strong indicators that suggest a professional or specialized environment.

Overall, the primary challenge in this lighting context is to provide adequate illumination for the task being performed. This requires targeted and directed light sources to avoid shadows and ensure precise work on the material being handled.

1. In the image, the central lighting problem appears to be insufficient illumination of the subject's hands working with the wire. The source of light is not directly shining on the person's hands or the task at hand, creating a shadowed effect and making it difficult to see the details of the work being done.

2. To address this issue, the lighting solution demonstrated is using a flashlight to illuminate the area where the wire is being worked with. The person is holding the flashlight in such a way that the beam is directed towards their hands and the task, thus providing better visibility for the activity at hand.

3. The specific lighting product mentioned or shown is a flashlight, which serves as an improvised solution to increase localized light where it's needed most.

4. The lighting context in this image seems to be focused on the task at hand, likely related to electrical work or repairs, given the presence of the wire and the tools being used. The mood is practical and hands-on, indicating that the person may be working independently or as a part of a DIY project.

In this video frame, we see an individual working in what appears to be a rustic wooden kitchen with shelves and drawers. There are some specific lighting challenges and possible solutions visible:

1. **Lighting Problems**: The space is dimly lit, which might make it difficult for the person to read or perform precise tasks such as cooking or food preparation. The natural light coming through the window doesn't seem sufficient to fully illuminate the workspace.

2. **Lighting Solutions/Techniques**: The person appears to be installing lights, likely intending to enhance the lighting in this area. One can infer that they may be using task or ambient lighting to improve visibility and create a more comfortable and functional kitchen environment.

3. **Specific Lighting Products**: It's not entirely clear from the image what specific lighting products are being used, but it appears that they might be adding LED strip lights or under-cabinet lighting fixtures to brighten up the space.

4. **Lighting Context**: The room is a kitchen, which suggests a task context of food preparation and cooking. The mood seems practical and focused on improving the lighting for better safety and functionality in the kitchen area.

Overall, the video frame shows a process of addressing lighting issues by installing additional lights to improve visibility and create a more inviting and functional space.

In this video frame, we can observe a person working with electrical cables and components, which suggests a setting related to electronics repair or installation. Here's an analysis of the lighting aspects:

1. Lighting Problems/Challenges: The primary focus is on the task at hand – working with wires and connectors. The image shows a person holding a cable, possibly inspecting or connecting it to another device. There might be insufficient lighting in the area where the person is working, which could make it difficult to see small components or to distinguish between different types of cables.

2. Lighting Solutions/Techniques: The lighting solution shown here is using a flashlight to illuminate the immediate area of interest. This technique allows the person to focus on the specific task at hand without the need for bright overhead lights, which could cause glare or distraction from the surrounding environment.

3. Lighting Products Mentioned/Shown: There is no product-specific information visible in this frame, but it demonstrates a common tool – a flashlight, which serves as an ad hoc lighting solution in this context.

4. Lighting Context (Room Type, Task, Mood): The image seems to be taken indoors in a workspace or garage setting, where the task at hand is likely related to electronics repair, installation, or maintenance. The mood of the scene appears focused and practical, as the individual is engaged in their work with minimal distractions.

1. There are no direct lighting problems visible in this image; however, it appears that the person is working with a piece of wood and is possibly preparing to install or repair some elements that require good visibility. The task at hand seems to be related to construction, furniture making, or a similar activity where attention to detail is important.

2. The lighting solutions being demonstrated include using an LED strip light for illuminating the working area. This type of lighting product is known for its flexibility and ability to be used in various configurations, which is evident from the person holding the LED strip. It seems that the LED lights are being strategically placed along the edge of the workpiece or on the work surface itself to provide adequate lighting without casting harsh shadows.

3. The specific lighting product shown is an LED strip light, which is a versatile choice for indoor lighting tasks due to its ability to conform to different shapes and contours.

4. The lighting context in this image suggests a workspace or a home setting where someone is performing a task that requires adequate lighting, possibly related to woodworking, crafting, or DIY projects. The focus on detail in the person's action implies the need for good visibility to ensure accuracy and quality in the work being done.

The image shows a person sitting at a wooden table with various electronic equipment, including what appears to be cables and possibly a microphone or other audio device. There are several lighting-related issues visible:

1. Insufficient illumination: The area around the person's hands is dimly lit, which might make it difficult for the individual to work or focus on small details.
2. Shadow cast by objects and the person: The light source seems to be coming from the top left corner, casting a shadow over the workspace. This could affect the visibility of the objects on the table.
3. Uneven lighting: There is an uneven distribution of light on the table surface, with brighter spots closer to the light source and darker areas further away.
4. Glare and reflection: The shine on the wooden table suggests that the light source might be directly above or at a direct angle to it, causing glare and reflections that can strain the eyes.

As for solutions or techniques being demonstrated:

1. It's not clear if any specific lighting products are being used or shown in this frame. However, the presence of a cable with an adapter suggests that power management might be relevant to the discussion of lighting in this context.
2. The person appears to be working on a microphone setup or recording equipment, which may require specialized lighting for voiceover work or audio production. This could include soft diffused light or directional lights to avoid glare and ensure even illumination across the workspace.
3. Adjusting the position of the light source might help alleviate shadows and improve overall ambient lighting. The use of a reflector, fill light, or adjustable standing lamp could provide better control over the lighting conditions.
4. Experimenting with different types of lighting bulbs or LED panels that are designed to reduce glare could help improve visibility while reducing eye strain.

The lighting context here appears to be a workspace for recording audio, editing video, or working on microphone setups. The mood seems focused and professional, as the individual is likely engaged in tasks related to sound or voice production.

1. The lighting problem visible in this image is uneven illumination across the workbench. There are darker areas where shadows might be causing difficulty for the person working there.
2. A solution being demonstrated here is the use of a light source (likely an LED panel) attached to the backsplash or edge of the table, which is providing additional lighting to the area where the person is focused on his task. This setup ensures that the workspace is well-lit and the individual can see what he's doing clearly.
